elements.title: trade-dollar locket (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the trade-dollar locket (example pictured) has also been referred to as an opium dollar?

elements.title: Henry Bell (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that despite having never played college football, Henry Bell was able to make the roster of the NFL's Denver Broncos and served as one of the team's starting running backs in their inaugural season?

elements.title: In the Land of Invented Languages (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the author of In the Land of Invented Languages lived in the same town as a fluent Klingon speaker?

elements.title: Elisabeth Anderson Sierra (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Elisabeth Anderson Sierra, nicknamed the "milk goddess", holds the Guinness World Record for the largest individual donation of breast milk?

elements.title: Chicago-style barbecue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Chicago-style barbecue is cooked in an aquarium smoker?

elements.title: Baruch Cohen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that two months after the Black September Organization assassinated Mossad operative Baruch Cohen in Madrid, his role in uncovering a Syria-directed spy ring in Israel was revealed?

elements.title: Gladys Quander Tancil (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Gladys Quander Tancil interpreted the lives of her enslaved ancestors at George Washington's Mount Vernon for more than twenty years?

elements.title: Kabul synagogue (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the two residents of the Kabul synagogue argued with each other so much that the Taliban imprisoned them both?
